results.title: Sadness: a monologue by William Yang
results.creator_credit: Tony Ayres, Megan McMurchy, Michael McMahon and Film Australia
results.brief_description: Based on photographer William Yang’s one man stage show, “Sadness” chronicles two diverging narratives through the use of slide photography, oral history and stylised recreation. One story follows Yang’s pilgrimage into the heart of the North Queensland sugar cane fields as he investigates the murder of his uncle Fang Yuen. The other is a series of moving portraits of the many friends and lovers Yang has lost to AIDS. Director Tony Ayres skillfully weaves these two separate stories together creating a powerful testament to family, friends, love and loss. Cinematography by Tristan Milani. Narrated by William Yang.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Tony Ayres, Megan McMurchy, Michael McMahon and Film Australia

results.title: Bronzed Aussie gods
results.creator_credit: Michael Murray, Nick Bleszinski and Light Source Films
results.brief_description: The Beach is part of Australia’s cultural landscape, the surf lifesavers the guardians of this beautiful, but potentially dangerous terrain. Saving lives is not all these lifesavers do, at the end of every summer the Australian National Surf Lifesaving Titles (affectionately referred to as the “Aussies” by lifesaving aficionados) are held in April on the Gold Coast. Featuring over 6,000 competitors, this prestigious event is the second largest sporting event in number of athletes only to the Olympics. ‘Bronzed Aussie Gods’ follows three groups of men and women in training as lifesavers, performing real life rescues, enjoying their work, and vying for title glory. Interspersed with their plight is a trip down memory lane courtesy of archival footage capturing the changing customs and costumes that celebrate Australia’s unique relationship with the beach. This results in a film which celebrates Australian beach culture and maps the evolution of a strong aspect of Australian identity.

results.title: Empty arms, broken hearts
results.creator_credit: Iain E. Gillespie, Jacqueline Gillespie, Australia. Special Broadcasting Service and AFFC
results.brief_description: A film by publicised parents of kidnapped children, Jacqueline and Iain Gillespie, this documentary attempts to enlighten it’s viewer of the torment and distress involved in losing a child to kidnapping by a parent. It also raises the problems associated with bringing into place international treaties designed to allow a country authority to pursue the kidnapping parent and return the child to his/her other parent at home.

results.title: Last paradise. Parts 1-3
results.creator_credit: Gian Manara and Australia. Special Broadcasting Service
results.brief_description: An educational documentary in three parts, ‘Last Paradise’ examines the contrasts between contemporary and traditional lifestyles in Papua New Guinea through the lives of flight crew members working for the country’s national airline, Air Niugini. While they enjoy the privileged lifestyles of international travellers, these men and women return each year to the villages and tribes to which they belong. The film makers contrast the work and leisure activities of the flight crew personnel abroad with the traditional culture, lore, and tribal values that continue to be the mainstay of the villages they come from to comment on the changes that are facing the inhabitants of Papua New Guinea and its surrounding islands at the end of the twentieth century.

results.title: Red light in full flight
results.creator_credit: Samia Mikhail, Sharyn Prentice and Flamingo Star Films
results.brief_description: The culture of Middle eastern belly dancing in Australia is a prolific one, with belly dancers in Australia outnumbering dancers in other countries. The director gleans anecdotes about the history of this sensual womens’ dance and interviews Australian dancers about their dance, their lives and their culture. It also discusses the importance of traditional cultural dance in women’s lives.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Samia Mikhail, Sharyn Prentice and Flamingo Star Films

results.title: Romanov
results.creator_credit: Yuri Sokol, Sokol Films and Australia. Special Broadcasting Service
results.brief_description: The history of the influential royal Romanov family and their descendants search for identity are the subject of this SBS funded documentary. The tape covers present attitudes in Russia towards a monarchy, and follows the story of one Australian Romanov member who, with his wife, returns to Russia to research his heritage.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Yuri Sokol, Sokol Films and Australia. Special Broadcasting Service

results.title: Some American feminists
results.creator_credit: Margaret Wescott, Nicole Brossard, Luce Guilbeault and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: This film was shot in New York City in 1975 and 1976…and is not intended as a definitive statement on feminism, the women, or the movement, but rather a documentary exploring the experiences, feelings and philosophies of some American feminists. It contains a series of interviews, interspersed with newsreel footage, placing the American feminist movement in a historical perspective. Six of the women who gave impetus to the movement, Betty Friedan (author), Kate Millett (author and sculptor), Rita Mae Brown (author and poet), Lila Karp (writer and professor of women’s studies), Ti-Grace Atkinson (feminist theorist and activist) and Margo Jefferson (writer and critic), discuss those issues that most concern them, and which are still being debated. Interviewer: Luce Guilbeault.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Margaret Wescott, Nicole Brossard, Luce Guilbeault and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: Beating the drum
results.creator_credit: Fiona Cochrane, Louise Hubbard, F-Reel Pty Ltd and Film Finance Corporation Australia
results.brief_description: Melbourne has proven to be a mecca of sorts for musicians, with virtually any style of music being performed in clubs and halls across the city at any one time. ‘Beating the drum’ showcases some of these extraordinary performers who have migrated to Australia- some retain their traditional style, others have blended it in collaboration with other musicians. Both methods reflect the bigger issue of the cultural appropriation of music- whether there is such a thing, is there a right and wrong way to do it, how does Aboriginal music fit into this notion, and what we mean by world music? Musicians, academics, broadcasters and World Music aficionados take up this discussion through words and music. Musicians include: Xylouris Ensemble, Kavisha Mazzella and La Voce Della Luna, George Telek, Rembetika Compania, Terrasphere, Tom E. Lewis, Inka Marka, Taksim, Thula Sana, Adzohu, Fronteras, Vladimir Kocibelli, Petrunka, Tsicaderis Ensemble and Ta’Esh Fa’Esh.

results.title: Purple haze
results.creator_credit: Rachael Hynes, Katherine Hynes, Ian Stevenson and Bondi Beech
results.brief_description: This documentary follows the story of 5 Jacaranda Queen candidates in the country town of Grafton, NSW, before and after the crowning. It examines all the trials and tribulations of preparing for the ceremony and coping with not only losing, but winning. Their candid experience is reflected against the background of Grafton, a town living through tough economic times, the community expectation of the events, and the impact or relevance it has on their lives. Produced with assistance from the Australian Film Finance Corporation.

results.title: Some people have to suffer
results.creator_credit: Christopher Pinney and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: This film documents a community’s struggle to survive in the face of government indifference and the political and financial clout of industrial developers. In 1953 the residents of Bridgeview, British Columbia, were promised sewers; following years of debate, frustration, meetings and verbiage, construction started in 1977. The film interviews some of the residents, who state their opinions frankly both to the camera and at meetings. When the film was shown at the Habitat conference in Vancouver, 1976, press coverage noted: “The Third World is merely twenty miles from the site of Habitat.” Narration: Boyce Richardson.
